intro: Smilax pygmaea, commonly known as the dwarf greenbriar, is a low-growing vine native to the southeastern United States. It features stout, thorned stems that creep along the ground, often forming dense mats. The plant has heart-shaped, waxy leaves with a distinctive veining pattern, and it produces small, yellowish-green flowers in the spring. Its fruit is a red, fleshy berry that ripens in the fall, attracting various wildlife. Smilax pygmaea is a hardy plant that thrives in moist, shaded environments, often found in woodland areas.
